newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Argentina global bond issue expected next week.
newsitem.headline: Argentina global bond issue expected next week.

text.p: Argentina's $2.0 billion global bond is expected to be launched on January 21 or 22 following completion of the issuer's roadshows, joint lead manager Merrill Lynch said Wednesday.
J.P. Morgan is the other joint lead.
The two-tranche issue will offer maturities of five and 20 years.

Pricing has not yet been set, but bankers said they expect the five-year tranche to pay some 300-325 basis points over comparable Treasuries and the 20-year tranche to pay roughly 500 basis points over the benchmark.
Argentina is rated B1 by Moody's Investors Service and BB-minus by Standard and Poor's Corp.
The 20-year tranche is the longest dollar bond ever issued by Argentina. It sold 30-year bonds denominated in German marks last year.
Merrill Lynch and Argentine officials were finishing up the Asian roadshow with a presentation in Hong Kong on Wednesday after visiting Seoul and Taipei earlier this week.
Merrill Lynch said that 50 to 80 investors attended each of the Asian roadshows, with both commercial banks and institutional investors represented.

Joaquin Cottani, Argentina's financial representative in the U.S., said this US$2.0 billion issue and US$2.0 billion saved from 1996 borrowing will satisfy about 40 percent of Argentina's planned US$8.5 billion borrowing through foreign debt issues in 1997.
Many attending the Asian roadshows would be first-time investors in Argentine fixed-rate paper, Cottani said.
Asian investors, which tend to prefer shorter-dated paper, are expected to participate in the five-year tranche.
Roadshows will be held in Frankfurt and London starting on Thursday and a New York roadshow will be completed next Tuesday. Launch is expected soon after the New York roadshow.
